explanation: To determine whether process_param__empty participates in direct or indirect recursion you must inspect any functions that can call it and any functions reachable from those callers (to see if any chain leads back to process_param__empty). Therefore include: 1) Direct callers: process_short_param and process_long_param — their bodies may call back (directly or via other callees). 2) All callees of those callers (process_param__all_cpus, process_param__threads, process_param__thread_per_conn, process_param__epoll, process_param__poll, process_param__select, process_param__tiny, process_param__medium, process_param__large, process_param__shared, process_param__single, process_param__unique, process_param__connections, process_param__timeout, process_param__version, plus process_param__date_header and process_param__help which are called by process_long_param) — each must be checked for calls that eventually return to process_param__empty. 3) The higher-level callers process_short_params_str and process_params (callers of process_short_param/process_long_param) — include them because recursion can involve longer chains that travel up and down caller/callee relationships. Inspecting these symbols allows construction of the call chains needed to prove presence or absence of indirect recursion.
